bioghist.p: Hobson Pittman (1899-1972) grew up in North Carolina and moved to Pennsylvania when he was 18. He attended Pennsylvania State College, studied at the Carnegie Institute of Technology, and for a number of years spent his summers at the art colony in Woodstock, New York. He was made director of art at the Friends Central Day School near Philadelphia in 1931, taught in the summer school at the Pennsylvania State University from 1932 to 1965, and, in 1949, became a member of the faculty at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts. A painter as well as a teacher, Pittman won numerous prizes and awards for his art and his paintings hang in many museums, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Whitney Museum of American Art, and the North Carolina Museum of Art.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of the scrapbooks and correspondence of Hobson Pittman (1929-1966) and papers related to the Hobson Pittman estate and the Friends of the Hobson Pittman House (1979-1989). The scrapbooks include newspaper clippings, magazine articles, and brochures for exhibitions. Correspondence is with friends and family, students, galleries, and art dealers.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
